threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: in ARM you have things like the Snoop Control Unit which handles L1D coherency on multiprocessor systems

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: for motherboards that have multiple CPU sockets the CPUs themselves have coherency protocols for this kind of scenario

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: that is what the Intel Quick Path Interconnect (QPI) and now the Ultra Path Interconnect (UPI) is for

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [AMD has its own shenanigans for that kind of stuff too, of course]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: all of these are hardware functions that are "invisible" to the software

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i say "invisible" because of course there are possible timing channels from the microarchitecture that could be visible to the software state

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the `perf` subsystem in linux has been around for a while; the entire hardware monitoring stuff in both ARM and x86 have been around for quite some time too

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: (the `perf` subsystem was made in response to having those features available, iirc)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: but to use monitoring events you _have_ to get the kernel involved

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you can't use a `wrmsr` from userland, and you need to use MSRs if you want to use the hardware monitoring counters (x86)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: in ARM you would need to access the CoreSight subsystem, which is memory mapped on the PPB of the ARM cores, and for that you once again need to involve the kernel

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the kernel side of the GPU driver for the Apple Silicon M1 chips is written in Rust

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [for multiple reasons, chief among them was to push the Rust subsystem in the kernel to the limit to see what else was needed]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: but, that means you need some Rust bindings

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: expect the same thing for C++

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: and yes, if i recall properly, they tried C++ in the kernel once (for stuff related to filesystems)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: it just did not work out

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: oh, and if you're writing a kernel subsystem in C++, you have to deal with that pesky name mangling

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: recall that your subsystem needs to expose an API that other parts of the kernel can utilize

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: this includes kernel modules, for which symbols need to resolve dynamically

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: and then, there's the thing that name mangling is not standard in C++

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so now you may end up in a situation where if you built the kernel with compiler A and your module with compiler B then some symbols may not be found

threads.author: madman.in.a.box

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: There are a ton of projects in c++. But not as many (different) operating systems. You already have windows and linux. No need to write another one in c++. People focus on applications instead.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: That argument kinda reads as "we use rust to have an excuse to use rust"

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: Isn't rust solving that problem of intercompatibility issues between compiler A and B by... Only having compiler A? :kek:

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the thing is that you could argue there are benefits to using Rust in the kernel (and the subsystem was already there)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: and yes, you could potentially make the same arguments there for C++

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: but as far as i am aware, the full OOP facilities of Rust are not used in the kernel

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so now, if you were to translate that to C++, you're using C++ without the OOP stuff

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you may as well just use C

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i have not looked into this yet

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if you look at kernel API, you will find that a lot of the dynamic memory allocations are automatically deallocated

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: pretty much all of the subsystems have automatically managed allocators

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: there are also a bunch of static analysis tools that are run on the kernel to find these dangling pointers of yours (the analysis is undecidable for the general case, but the tools are pretty good at it)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the rest of your stuff is pretty moot, to say the least

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: macros are used in C++ as well, and the macros you find in the kernel are mainly either to create declarative data structures or to deal with things that involve some inline assembly

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i don't really see how C allows for the compiler not to optimize though (and for it to generate larger binaries)

threads.content: [source: i've done internal work on compilers before]

Yes. We had to disable secure boot. We tried with Secure Boot but we kept running into issues.

If we've just been running around in circles like idiots and there is a better way and we can just have the standard, vanilla accept our regulatory with no kernel mods and with Secure Boot enabled (since that will be the default), that will be awesome.

Otherwise, that's still okay with us.

threads.content: [and yes, if you're tampering with the wireless regulatory domain then you're very likely doing something you should not be doing]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i can not think of a legitimate reason to bypass/modify the kernel's wireless regulatory domain database

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: one of my wireless cards from QCA has a piece of firmware which reads the card's EEPROM and loads the regdom from there

threads.author: dr.sudo
threads.content:
Yeah, good luck explaining that to cyber. They're hard-headed as hell. And even then, they take FOREVER to approve new stuff. And depending on what you're asking for, it highly depends on who's in charge. This is a long story that I won't get into, but even if you do so happen to get an IT/Cyber manager that agrees with you 100%, you'll likely wait months or years to get it implemented.

I'm telling you, it took YEARS for us to finally get Linux workstations despite us proving the net benefits and the managers at the time being supportive.

And keep in mind, I agree with you. We should be more open to some of these platforms. But you'll be spending a huge majority of your time fighting IT and filling out paperwork than getting anything done at that point. And honestly, you'd do better elsewhere.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: Think of the kernel as a layered architecture. You have your subsystems (I2C, SPI, PCIe...). For the subsystems to interact with the hardware, you need drivers for your hardware. You need to make your drivers and register them with that subsystem. Now, you have drivers that make use of a particular subsystem. For example, say that you're dealing with an SGP30 sensor. That is an air quality/chemical sensor. It uses I2C to communicate with your platform.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: In Linux, the driver for that is in the IIO subsystem. It registers itself in the IIO subsystem of the kernel, and it calls upon functions from the I2C subsystem to perform reads/writes to the sensor.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: The I2C subsystem then talks to your I2C controller driver (a platform driver) to actually access the hardware.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: The driver for the SGP30 does not add any device nodes in `devfs`.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: Why? Because data from the IIO subsystem is not exposed in `devfs`. Instead, it gets exposed in `sysfs`. In particular, in `/sys/bus/iio/devices`.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: This is to say: every subsystem in the kernel has its own set of bindings for userspace to use.

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: Sometimes it is under something in `devfs`, like the modern way of handling GPIOs (an `ioctl()`-based interface using whatever `gpiochip` gets exposed in `devfs`). Sometimes it is something under `sysfs`, like the aforementioned IIO subsystem. Sometimes, it is neither, like stuff that deals with the PCIe subsystem at a low level.

threads.content: Finally figured out what the `--kernel_offset` does in `mkbootimg`, rather, what u-boot does with the addresses.

threads.author: xhivo97
threads.content: <https://elixir.bootlin.com/u-boot/v2025.07/source/boot/image-android.c#L257>

threads.author: xhivo97
threads.content: This function is kind of cursed

threads.author: xhivo97
threads.content:
If your image is using the default `mkbootimg` offsets, it will use your environment variable `kernel_addr_r`. Fine, this is easy enough.

_But_ if your ~~image~~ kernel happens to be uncompressed, for whatever reason, it will use it in-place. Meaning now your `load address + page size` has to be properly aligned for your CPU.

In my example with a non compressed kernel u-boot ignores `kernel_addr_r=0x82000000`, so I have to use `loadaddr=0x82000000 - my_page_size`.

`loadaddr` is where my `boot.img`, or boot partition, is loaded.

Finally, if the image is not using defaults it will use the ones you pass to `mkbootimg`. I pity the person who happens to specify one, but is for some reason using defaults lol. Rip their alignment.

This is very inconsistent IMO

threads.author: xhivo97
threads.content: and not that well documented but I was a fool to not go to the source code earlier (not sure if this is because this is a bootloader, but everything is quite easy to follow)

threads.content: Any reason why this can't at least print a warning? I doubt that there isn't enough information scattered in some header for a simple check here, maybe it should even fail if the kernel is not aligned (that would be my preference tbh)

threads.author: dr.sudo
threads.content:
I wonder if anyone has seen anything like this before. I'm using dual parallel QSPI in my setup and I've upgraded the kernel and my QSPI is no longer mounting properly anymore. I'll try to show this as best I can, but I get a bunch of magic bitmask errors.

From what I've looked into, at the front of each erase block it will look for that 0x1985. On the older kernel, it reads this correctly and I can mount and use QSPI with no issues. The second picture is what I get when I hexdump the partition. The third screenshot is what I get on the newer kernel.

The only difference is the 0x1985 vs 0x99C5.
0x1985  = 0001 1001 1000 0101
0x99C5 = **1**001 1001 **11**00 0101

I tried `dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/mtd4` and after doing a hexdump, I get the fourth picture. So, the bits that I bolded above are always being read high for some reason. Here's the weird part: after doing this, I switched back to the old kernel and I correctly see all zeros. It doesn't read those bits as high. So, clearly, the writes are being done correctly. It's just that for some odd reason, only those bits are being misread.

I've honestly never seen something like this before.

threads.author: dr.sudo
threads.content: No. Every 0x20000 bytes which is 128 KB. This is the erase block size. The QSPI I'm using has an erase block size of 64 KB and the dual parallel setup doubles it to 128 KB.

threads.author: dr.sudo
threads.content: Dual parallel means 2 QSPI chips being used simultaneously in parallel with separate data buses to increase transfer speed.
